titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by David Hobbs. Finding aid created by Emily Kramer, 2014.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-04-17T16:40-0400

did.unittitle: Jennifer (Sudie) Nostrand Papers

physdesc.extent: (5 record cartons, 1 small case, 1 oversize box)

did.abstract: The Jennifer (Sudie) Nostrand Collection laregly contains published copies of her poetry work from 1965 to 2013, with some unpublished materials related to the editing, publication, or review of her work.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged in chronological order by their publication date, or date of creation for papers. The collection was processed at the folder level.
See the Scope and Content Notes for more specific details about each series.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: NYU's Fales Library & Special Collections is not the copyright owner for this collection. Collection use is subject to all copyright laws. Researchers wishing to reproduce collection material should contact rights holders for permission.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers. Appointments are necessary for the use of manuscript and archival collections.
Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The collection was donated to NYU's Fales Library & Special Collections by Jennifer (Sudie) Nostrand between 2000 and 2006.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Jennifer (Sudie) Nostrand is a New York poet whose work has been published in such literary magazines as The California Quarterly, The Greensboro Review, the Manhattan Poetry Review—among many others.

In 1984 Nostrand released Joan, a piece on the French heroine Joan of Arc, with the Mimeograph Press as part of the St. Mark’s Church-in-the-Bowery’s Poetry Project. The March Street Press later published a collection of her works entitled The Paris Poems in 2004 and in 2010 Nostrand released Variations with the same independent publisher. In response to The Paris Poems, American poet, editor, and activist, Ron Kolm claimed that “Sudie Nostrand has that very rare ability to make the spiritual manifest ( The Paris Poems).”

Nostrand earned a Ph.D. in English Literature from New York University. In addition to her published work, Nostrand participated in various public readings in New York City. She has gone by various names throughout her career: Jennifer Nostrand, Jennifer Sudie Nostrand, S. Nostrand, and, simply, Sudie.
Sources: Nostrand, Sudie.”Biography.” Variations, Greensboro, North Carolina: March Street Press, 2010. Nostrand, Sudie. The Paris Poems, Greensboro, North Carolina: March Street Press, 2004.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); Jennifer (Sudie) Nostrand; MSS 082; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Jennifer (Sudie) Nostrand Collection contains published materials documenting Nostrand’s poetry career. Also included are unpublished papers related to Nostrand’s writing and editing process. The materials are from 1965–2013.
The collection is divided into four series:

Series I: Documents. This series contains papers related to Jennifer (Sudie) Nostrand’s writing, such as posters, flyers, listings, reviews, correspondence, editorial proofs, and copies of a personal bibliography.
Series II: Printed Materials. This series is comprised of original publications featuring Nostrand’s writings from 1965-2013.
Series III: Oversized Materials includes materials too large to be stored in records carton.
Series IV: Data Storage includes two floppy-disk copies of Nostrand’s bibliography, dated January 2005.

controlaccess.subject: American poetry |y 20th century |z Periodicals.
Poets |z United States.
St. Mark’s Church In-the-Bowery (New York, N.Y.). Poetry Project
